title: London, BL, Add. 12181
Digital Catalogue of Syriac Manuscripts in the British Library
sixth book of the select epistles of Severus of Antioch, translated from the Greek by the priest Athanasius of Nisibis, A.Gr. 980, A.D. 669.
First section, concerning bishops and the clergy, and their ordination.
To the bishop Constantine.
To Solon, bishop and metropolitan of Seleucia in Isauria.
To the same.
To the same.
To Peter, bishop of Apamea.
To the bishop Nicias.
To Castor, bishop of Perge.
To the dux (δούξ) Timostratus.
To Stephen, bishop of Tripolis.
To the bishop Eucharius.
To the abbat of the convent of Bassus.
To the priests Cosmas, Polyeuctus and Zeno .
To Entrechius (᾿Εντρέχιος), bishop of Anazarbus.
To Antonine, bishop of Aleppo.
To the same.
To the same.
To the chamberlain (κουβικουλάριος, κουβουκλάριος) Mishael (Michael, or Misael ?).
To Entrechius, bishop of Anazarbus.
To Solon, bishop of Seleucia in Isauria.
Letter, in the name of the synod of Antioch, to the bishops under (Peter) the metropolitan of Apamea.
To a Magister (Μάγιστρος).
To the Fathers.
To Solon, bishop of Seleucia in Isauria.
To Theotecnus the archiater.
To Dionysius, bishop of Tarsus.
To Solon, bishop of Selcucia in Isauria.
To Musonius and Alexander, vindices (βίνδικες) of Anazarbus.
To Philoxenus, bishop of Doliche.
To the monks of the convent of Mār Isaac.
To the clergy of Apamea.
Commonitorium to the bishops of Phoenicia.
To John, bishop of Alexandria the less (Alexandretta or Scandarūn).
To Dionysius, bishop of Tarsus.
To the bishops under the metropolitan of Apamea.
To the priest Eustathius.
To the deacon Eusebius of Apamea.
To Simeon, bishop of Kinnesrīn.
To the same.
To the clergy and magistracy of Apamea.
To the general (στρατηλάτης) Hypatius.
To Solon, bishop of Seleucia in Isauria.
To the Fathers.
To the abbat of the convent of Mār Simeon.
To Eutychianus, magistrate of Apamea.
To Conon, the chief officer of police.
To the clergy of Antaradus.
To Cassianus, bishop of Bostra.
To Philoxenus, bishop of Mabūg.
To the priests and abbats John and John, and others.
To the same.
To the priest Philip.
To the priests John and John, and others.
To the bishops from Syria, residing at Alexandria (Cassianus, Constantine, Antonine, and others).

Second section: concerning his own ordination, prior to his being made bishop; and concerning the precedence (προεδρία) of bishops, and another doubtful point; also concerning those who proclaim themselves bishops and perform the act of ordination, and concerning the proper ordination of bishops.
To the Patricians.
To the priests John and John.
To the orthodox laity of Emesa.
Third section: that it is not becoming for anyone to trouble himself about the private life of priests, but that he should merely inquire whether they are orthodox.
To the Comes Anastasius, the son of Sergius.
To Ammianus and Epagathus.
To the deacon Mishael.
To the patrician lady Caesaria.
Fourth section: that we should not hold communion with heretics indifferently or without examination; and how we should guard against being with them when they pray.
To Zachariah of Pelusium.
To the priest Ammonius, of Alexandria, concerning the naming of Peter (Mongus), who was bishop of Alexandrias.
To Dioscorus (II.), archbishop of Alexandria.
To Dionysius, bishop of Tarsus.
To Cosmas, abbat of the convent of Cyrus (?).
To the Comes John of Antaradus.
To the abbat John.
To the faithful in Antioch.
To Andrew the reader (ἀναγνώστης) and notary (νοτάριος).
To the patrician lady Caesaria.
Fifth section: concerning clergy or lay persons, who return from heresies to the church.
To the tribune (τριβοῦνος) John, in the name of the abbat Leontius.
To the bishop Nicias.
To the convent at Tagae.
To Theotecnus, the priest and archiater.
To Dionysius, bishop of Tarsus.

To those who say that it is necessary that persons who have participated in the doctrines of the council of Chalcedon, but who repent and anathematize the upholders of the doctrine of the two natures in our Lord Jesus Christ after the ineffable union, and run after the orthodox faith, should be anointed (baptised) afresh.
Eleventh section: that one should not become a monk, who can be of use to the orthodox faith in the public life of a citizen.
To the chamberlain Mishael.
To fill up the remaining leaves, the scribe has added some extracts from the writings of John Chrysostom.
From the eleventh homily on the epistle of S. Paul to the Ephesians.
From the first homily on the Gospel according to S. Matthew.
syrTitle: ܫܠܡ ܟܬܒܐ ܕܫܬܐ ܕܐܓܪ̈ܬܐ ܗܩ̈ܠܘܓܐ ܐܘܟܝܬ ܡܓ̈ܒܝܬܐ ܕܡܢ ܐܓܪ̈ܬܗ ܕܩܕܝܫܐ ܣܐܘܪܐ ܦܛܪܝܪܟܝܣ ܕܐܢܛܝܘܟܝܐ ܕܣܘܪܝܐ.

finalRubrics: ܫܠܡ ܟܬܒܐ ܕܫܬܐ ܕܐܓܪ̈ܬܐ ܗܩ̈ܠܘܓܐ ܐܘܟܝܬ ܡܓ̈ܒܝܬܐ ܕܡܢ ܐܓܪ̈ܬܗ ܕܩܕܝܫܐ ܣܐܘܪܐ ܦܛܪܝܪܟܝܣ ܕܐܢܛܝܘܟܝܐ ܕܣܘܪܝܐ.
colophons: Colophon A subsequent note, in the handwriting of the scribe, informs us that this volume was written for Elisha, metropolitan of Nisibis . ܠܬܫܒܘܚܬܐ ܘܠܐܝܩܪܐ ܕܬܠܝܬܝܘܬܐ ܩܕܝܫܬܐ ܐܬܚ̇ܦܛ ܘܩܢܗ̇ ܠܣܝܡܬܐ ܗܕܐ ܪܘܚܢܝܬ̣ܐ. ܚܣܝܐ ܡܪܝ ܐܠܝܫ݊ܥ ܡܝܛܪܘܦܘܠܝܛܝܣ ܕܢܨܝܒܝܢ ܡܕܝܢܬܐ ܪܚ̇ܡܬ ܠܡܫܝܚܐ. ܐܝܟ ܕܠܝܘܬܪܢܐ ܕܢܦܫܗ ܘܕܟܠܗܘܢ ܪ̈ܚܡܝ ܐܠܗܐ. ܐܠܐ ܟܠ ܕܫ̇ܐܠ ܠܗ ܠܟܬܒܐ ܗܢܐ ܕܢܩܪܐ ܒܗ ܏ܘܫ..
